column1: The first known European exploration of the area was in 1774
column2: when Juan Bautista De Anza passed through on the first overland expedition of Las Californias
column3: from New Spain-Mexico towards Monterey Bay.  The area was originally developed in 1837 with the Mexican land grant from Governor Juan Bautista Alvarado to Ygnacio Palomares and Ricardo Vejar for the Rancho San Jose
column4: then in Alta California. It later became known as La Cienega Mud Springs
column5: so named because of local mud springs that created a riparian marsh and healing place.  Palomares and Vejar conducted sheep and cattle operations on Rancho San Jose
column6: also growing crops for consumption by the residents of the rancho.  In the early 1860s
column7: a severe drought decimated the ranch's population of sheep and cattle.  Ygnacio Palomares died in 1864
column8: and his widow began selling the ranch land in 1865.  Vejar lost his share by foreclosure to two Los Angeles merchants
column11: Schlesinger and Tischler sold the ranch to Louis Phillips.The arrival of the Los Angeles and San Gabriel Valley Railroad in 1887
column12: later purchased by Santa Fe Railroad
column13: led to La Cienega Mud Springs being first mapped. The ensuing land boom resulted in the formation of the San Jose Ranch Company
column14: which first laid out streets.  Small businesses began to open soon thereafter
column15: and the city took on a new name: San Dimas. Growth was rapid
column16: and San Dimas soon became an agricultural community. Wheat and other Midwestern United States crops were planted first; then orange and lemon groves covered the town and the San Gabriel Valley. At one time
column17: four citrus packing houses and a marmalade factory were located in San Dimas. The Sunkist name originated here
column18: first spelled "Sunkissed." Oranges were the major crop and business in San Dimas until the mid-20th century.

column1: The majority of the city lies within the Bonita Unified School District and students attend San Dimas High School.
